The separation of sounds into two classes according aa pitch · is present or absent is implied (unless, to be sure, pitch is attributed to all sounds whatsoever). The first classification we meet with is that by which sounds which have a pitch are divided into two groups according to the nature of that pitch. Ψόφοι, he says (Ptolemy, Herm, 1. iv„ p. 8 Wallis), are either ἰσότονον or ἀνισότονοι; the former are sounds which are un- ehangeable in the matteras pitch (ἀπαράλλακτον κατὰ τὸν τόνον), the latter are those which change their pitch (παρολ- λάσσοντες).’
